This adaptation allows the fungus to colonize and proliferate in ecological niches with high salinity, such as seawater, salterns, and hypersaline lakes.

The fungus exhibits a dark-colored, yeast-like morphology and is capable of producing melanin, a pigment that provides protection against environmental stressors, such as UV radiation and oxidative damage. This pigmentation contributes to the characteristic black or dark-brown appearance of the fungal colonies.

Hortaea werneckii EXF-2000 has been studied for its potential applications in various fields, including bioremediation, where it may be used to remove heavy metals or other pollutants from hypersaline environments. Additionally, its unique adaptations to high-salt conditions have made it a subject of interest in the field of extremophile research, as it provides insights into the strategies employed by organisms to survive and thrive in challenging environmental conditions.
